current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To establish the Railroad Emergency Services Preparedness, Operational Needs, and Safety Evaluation
			 (RESPONSE) Subcommittee under the Federal Emergency Management Agency’s
			 National Advisory Council to provide recommendations on emergency
			 responder training and resources relating to hazardous materials incidents
			 involving railroads, and for other purposes.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 508 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002

text.#text: Such other qualified individuals as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
that have the requisite technical knowledge and expertise
			 to address rail safety issues, including members from the following
			 disciplines:

text.#text: Members of the

Emergency management and emergency response providers, including fire service, law enforcement,
			 hazardous materials response, and emergency medical services.

State, local, and tribal government officials with expertise in preparedness, protection, response,
			 recovery, and mitigation, including Adjutants General.
Elected State, local, and tribal government executives.
Such other individuals as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Railroad Emergency Services Preparedness, Operational Needs, and Safety Evaluation Subcommittee

the rail industry;
the oil industry;
the communications industry;

representatives from national Indian organizations;
technical experts; and

vendors, developers, and manufacturers of systems, facilities, equipment, and capabilities for

Representatives of such other stakeholders and interested and affected parties as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Office of Protection and National Preparedness

Railroad Emergency Services Preparedness, Operational Needs, and Safety Evaluation Subcommittee

text.#text: After the initial meeting, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
and the program offices for emergency responder training and resources
			 shall

			 engaged in federally funded
			 research and academic institutions engaged in relevant work and research,
			 which are not represented on the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Railroad Emergency Services Preparedness, Operational Needs, and Safety Evaluation Subcommittee

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
to consider new and
			 developing technologies and methods that may be beneficial to preparedness
			 and
			 response to rail incidents.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Railroad Emergency Services Preparedness, Operational Needs, and Safety Evaluation Subcommittee

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall develop recommendations for improving emergency responder training
			 and
			 resource allocation, including the following:
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Railroad Emergency Services Preparedness, Operational Needs, and Safety Evaluation Subcommittee

text.#text: The

Quality and application of training for local emergency first responders related to rail hazardous
			 materials incidents, with a particular focus on local emergency
			 responders and small communities near railroads, including the following:
Ease of access to relevant training for local emergency first responders, including an analysis of—
the number of individuals being trained;
the number of individuals who are applying;
whether current demand is being met;
current challenges; and
projected needs.

Modernization of course content related to rail hazardous materials incidents, with a particular
			 focus on response to the exponential rise in oil shipments by rail.

Evaluation of content across agencies and the private sector to provide complementary opportunities
			 for courses and avoid overlap, including the following:
Overlap of course content among agencies.
Assess the need for integrated course content through public-private partnerships.

Regular and ongoing evaluation of course opportunities, adaptation to emerging trends, agency and
			 private sector outreach, effectiveness and ease of access for local
			 emergency responders.
Online training platforms, train-the-trainer and mobile training options.

Effectiveness of funding levels related to training local emergency responders for rail hazardous
			 materials incidents, with a particular focus on local emergency responders
			 and small communities, including the following:
Minimizing overlap in resource allocation among agencies.
Minimizing overlap in resource allocation among agencies and private sector.

Maximizing public-private partnerships where funding gaps exists for specific training or
			 cost-saving measures can be implemented to increase training
			 opportunities.
Adaptation of priority settings for agency funding allocations in response to emerging trends.

Evaluation of historic levels of funding across agencies and private sector for rail hazardous
			 materials incidents.

Assessment of the need for increase funding for agencies and specific agencies where funding would
			 be most effective.

Strategy for integration of commodity flow studies, mapping, and access platforms for local
			 emergency responders and how to increase the rate of access to the
			 individual responder in existing or emerging communications technology.

The lack of emergency response plans for rail, similar to existing law related to maritime and
			 stationary facility emergency response plans, including the following:
Provisions of law relating to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know Act of 1986
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know Act of 1986

text.#text: How the industry would implement such plans.

The thresholds and availability of emergency plans for each train related to hazardous materials in
			 its cargo.
Gaps in existing regulations across agencies.
Development of a train incident database, including the following:
An assessment of the appropriate agency to host the database.
A definition of incident that would constitute the level of reporting from the industry.
The projected cost of such a database and how that database would be maintained and enforced.

Increasing access to relevant, useful, and timely information for the local emergency responder,
			 including the following:

Evaluation of existing information that the emergency responder can access, what the current rate
			 of access and usefulness is for the emergency responder, and what current
			 information should remain and what should be reassessed.

Utilization of existing technology in the hands of the first responder to maximize delivery of
			 useful and timely information for training or in the event of an incident.

Assessment of emerging communications technology that could assist the emergency responder in the
			 event of a rail hazardous materials incident.

Determination of the most efficient agencies and offices for the implementation of the
			 recommendations, including—

recommendations that can be implemented without congressional action and appropriate time frames
			 for such actions; and
recommendations that would require congressional action.
